answers.answer: HiThese may be pressure sores or may be contact dermatitis. How old is the patient? Are there other underlying disease conditions like diabetes ? Can the person move around or at least move the extremities?The sores should be cleaned and the feet be protected. Soft,wide and open slippers may be used. Do not allow the feet to rest directly on the hard surface. Moisturize the lower extremities to avoid dryness and irritation. Do no allow the patient to wear closed shoes that may be constricting and may decrease blood follow. Massage the areas gently to improve circulation. You may elevate the leg when the patient is at rest to allow good circulation.Pressure sores take place when patients stay in one position for long periods. This usually takes place in neurologically impaired patients especially those with loss of pain or touch sensation.A dermatitis should also be noted. Have these sores closely followed up by your doctor. It is important that antibiotics be administered and proper wound care be given.

question: I know someone that is confined to a wheel chair and is getting these blisters on the heel of their feet.  No one seems to know where they are coming from; the doctor has instructed the person to where a foam boot to sleep in and just leave on all the time.  A culture was taken of some of the fluid and it was not infected.  Do you have any idea how these blisters could be occuring?  Is this common for people confined to a wheel chair?  The person is a special needs individual and can't tell us how he is feeling or what might be happening to cause this.  I do know that they are taking several weeks to heal.This discussion is related tohttp://www.medhelp.org/posts/show/239688.
title: Mysterious Blisters
